While not exclusively about flags, it provides the essential context for designing the puzzles that lead to flags, which is a critical aspect of flag design itself.
resources.source_subdomain: Flag Design and Scoring Models in Attack Labs

resources.title: Building and Troubleshooting a CTFd Scoreboard: A Guide
resources.description: A practical, hands-on guide to setting up a CTFd scoreboard using Docker on a virtual private server. This tutorial walks through the entire setup process, from installing dependencies to deploying the containers and troubleshooting common issues. It's a great resource for understanding the backend of a common scoring engine.
resources.source_subdomain: Flag Design and Scoring Models in Attack Labs

resources.title: Cyber Security Capture the Flag (CTF) Series Part 1: Planning/Design
resources.description: This blog post provides a high-level overview of the planning and design phase for a CTF event. It covers creating a design document which includes the rules of play and details on the scoring system. It discusses the differences between Jeopardy-style and Attack-Defend CTFs, providing a foundational understanding of how scoring models fit into the overall event design.
resources.source_subdomain: Flag Design and Scoring Models in Attack Labs

packs.subdomain: Attacker Tooling Provisioning Within Labs

resources.title: Kali Linux Tools - Official Documentation
resources.description: Official documentation from the creators of Kali Linux, detailing the tools included with the distribution. It covers how to find, install, and manage tools using metapackages, which group tools by purpose (e.g., web, wireless, forensics).
resources.source_subdomain: Attacker Tooling Provisioning Within Labs

resources.title: Building a Pentest box with Ansible
resources.description: A step-by-step tutorial on how to automate the setup of a penetration testing machine using Ansible. It covers creating an Ansible playbook to install and configure common pentesting tools on a Debian-based system, similar to Kali or ParrotOS.
resources.source_subdomain: Attacker Tooling Provisioning Within Labs

resources.title: Automating Red Team Homelabs: Part 2  Build, Pentest, Destroy, and Repeat
resources.description: An advanced guide on fully automating the creation of a customized and updated Kali Linux Vagrant box using Packer. This allows for a repeatable process to build a fresh, fully provisioned attacker machine for each engagement, ensuring a clean state.
resources.source_subdomain: Attacker Tooling Provisioning Within Labs

resources.title: Commando VM: The Windows-based Penetration Testing Distribution
resources.description: The official GitHub repository for Commando VM, a Windows-based offensive security virtual machine distribution. The documentation covers installation and customization using Boxstarter, Chocolatey, and MyGet to provision a wide array of attacker tools on a Windows host.
resources.source_subdomain: Attacker Tooling Provisioning Within Labs

resources.title: Introduction to Lab Access
resources.description: Official guide from Hack The Box on how to connect to their lab environments. This resource explains the two primary methods for accessing attacker tooling: connecting your own virtual machine (like Kali) via OpenVPN or using their browser-based, pre-provisioned Parrot Security OS instance called Pwnbox.
resources.source_subdomain: Attacker Tooling Provisioning Within Labs

packs.subdomain: User Guidance, Hints, and Progressive Disclosure in Labs

resources.title: Progressive Disclosure
resources.description: This is the foundational article defining progressive disclosure, a core interaction design pattern for managing information complexity. It explains how deferring advanced or rarely used features to a secondary screen makes applications easier to learn and less error-prone, a key principle for designing guided labs.
resources.source_subdomain: User Guidance, Hints, and Progressive Disclosure in Labs

resources.title: Building your first HTB Machine: A beginner's guide
resources.description: An official guide from Hack The Box on the process of creating a vulnerable machine. It provides insights into the design philosophy, including creating a storyline, establishing a clear exploitation path, and avoiding rabbit holes, which are all crucial elements for guiding a user through a lab.
resources.source_subdomain: User Guidance, Hints, and Progressive Disclosure in Labs

resources.title: Web Security Academy: Free Online Training from PortSwigger
resources.description: While not a guide on *creating* labs, the Web Security Academy is a prime example of user guidance and progressive disclosure in action. Each topic provides detailed explanations, followed by an interactive lab to apply the knowledge. This structure serves as a real-world reference for how to scaffold learning in an attack lab context.
resources.source_subdomain: User Guidance, Hints, and Progressive Disclosure in Labs

resources.title: Tips and Tactics for Creating Your Own CTF Event
resources.description: This video provides practical advice on designing Capture The Flag (CTF) events. The speaker discusses how to write a good story, create a clear path for the user, and the importance of writing potential hints for when players get stuck, directly addressing the user's topic.
resources.source_subdomain: User Guidance, Hints, and Progressive Disclosure in Labs

resources.title: UX for Learning: Design Guidelines for the Learner Experience
resources.description: This article presents design guidelines derived from psychology and education research on learning with technology. It covers principles like using virtual agents for instruction and setting learning in a real-world context, which are highly relevant for designing effective guidance and hints in educational labs.
resources.source_subdomain: User Guidance, Hints, and Progressive Disclosure in Labs
